story:
About The Fest

SHEER QUEER Fest seeks to reclaim space in the punk and hardcore scene to promote and center the voices of angry queers, furious trans folks, and other rowdy gayz.

This year’s event is serving as a benefit for Youth On Fire, a Boston-based LGBTQ-inclusive drop in center for homeless and street-involved youth. As part of the Aids Action Committee, they provide housing, food, education and work support, medical care, as well as HIV and STI screenings. Within the last two years YOF has seen a doubling of their clients but are experiencing a huge budget cut and will potentially be facing a forced closure. Their services are crucial for not only queer youth but many others in the Boston area and they need our support.

The fest is set for October 14th from 1pm-11pm at The Democracy Center. The DC is working on becoming wheelchair accessible and should have a ramp installed and completed by the time of the fest. It can be accessed on the Dewolfe St. Side of the building. For more information about their plans to improve accessibility or to discuss your accessibility needs; call 617 492 8855

Sheer Queer Fest stands in solidarity with all marginalized communities and aims to combat racism, sexism, homo/transphobia, and other harmful behaviors present in radical spaces. Oppressive behavior will not be tolerated at the fest. BROS, FASCISTS, AND NAZIS FUCK OFF!

Bringing Bands To Boston

Our benefit for the fest got shut down by the cops (ACAB!) so we need to raise more money to make available to bands traveling to Boston for the fest. We as organizers acknowledge the importance to support our community members, and the particular financial difficulties queer, poc, and differently abled folk may face during travel. However, we cannot do this ourselves. 

To do this we are printing t-shirts designed by one of our organizers. Don't miss out on your chance to get your hands on this year's shirt design and help ensure that we can bring some really sick bands up for the fest!                                     

                              
 

Confirmed Bands

Solarized https://solarized.bandcamp.com/
Goolagoon https://goolagoonhc.bandcamp.com/
Pandemix https://pandemixpunx.bandcamp.com/
WIMP
Gash https://gashhh.bandcamp.com/
GUDSFORLADT https://gudsforladt.bandcamp.com/
Hussy https://hussypvd.bandcamp.com/
Public Disturbances https://nypd.bandcamp.com/
This Is Not Okay. https://thisisnotokay.bandcamp.com/
Corvus B. https://corvusb.bandcamp.com/album/france-later
+MORE TBA!!!

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone has cash to spare, and that's no problem! You can still help by telling your friends about this campaign and the fest.

Do you have clothes you've been meaning to donate? Youth on Fire is collecting clothing donations for the winter, especially larger sizes. We will have a drop off box at the fest so feel free to bring donations to the fest.

And don't forget, come to Boston on OCTOBER 14th to listen to all these great bands and spend time with some lovely queer folk.
story_txt:
About The Fest
SHEER QUEER Fest seeks to reclaim space in the punk and hardcore scene to promote and center the voices of angry queers, furious trans folks, and other rowdy gayz.This year’s event is serving as a benefit for Youth On Fire, a Boston-based LGBTQ-inclusive drop in center for homeless and street-involved youth. As part of the Aids Action Committee, they provide housing, food, education and work support, medical care, as well as HIV and STI screenings. Within the last two years YOF has seen a doubling of their clients but are experiencing a huge budget cut and will potentially be facing a forced closure. Their services are crucial for not only queer youth but many others in the Boston area and they need our support.
The fest is set for October 14th from 1pm-11pm at The Democracy Center. The DC is working on becoming wheelchair accessible and should have a ramp installed and completed by the time of the fest. It can be accessed on the Dewolfe St. Side of the building. For more information about their plans to improve accessibility or to discuss your accessibility needs; call 617 492 8855Sheer Queer Fest stands in solidarity with all marginalized communities and aims to combat racism, sexism, homo/transphobia, and other harmful behaviors present in radical spaces. story:
Who is Lower Leg?

Lower Leg is the artist name I gave myself. Lower Leg is the Westernized name of an Egyptian hieroglyph that looks like a leg or a foot. The hieroglyph stands for the English letter ‘B’; you see, I’m also known as Bella. My full birth name is Isabella India Holmes Zoltak, but if we’re being honest, no one will remember that. I’ve been diligently making art over the last several years, primarily focusing on creating bright, colorful, avant-garde faces. During this time I made the conscious decision that I wanted to be an artist, “when I grow up". In order to bring this goal into fruition, I've started this campaign to give my work a larger platform, and make my dream a reality.

What is "Let's Face It"?

"Let's Face It" is my most recent collection. It is a series of faces drawn from my imagination, paired with words that I felt called to share. The faces are bright, colorful, innocent, and abstract with surrealistic, exotic features. When I create faces I follow the basic guidelines that I know (eyes, nose, mouth, eyebrows, etc.) and then I add my own finesse.

This collection was especially inspired by my move to Maui, Hawaii. I came to the island on vacation and found that I didn’t want to leave; I stayed and created a new life for myself. The faces in the collection came out as I wrestled with the ups and downs of relocating 4,000 miles away from everything I knew. The words I paired with the faces were extremely relevant topics as I settled into my new home and new state of being.

Surrounded by fresh faces, I couldn’t help but look and become inspired. There is something beautifully telling in a person's face. I am especially drawn to eyes as most of us are. They are often seen as windows into a person's soul. Of course, a face is much more than just eyes. A face is the forefront of a person's presentation.

What are the Products?

The original pieces were made with multiple medias; gouache, pencil, marker, and pen on paper. I took each piece, cut it out with an X-ACTO knife, adhered it to black glitter paper, and framed it. I went on to create prints and stickers of the faces. For the prints, I settled on matte card stock paper with a thin (yet sturdy) backing and clear sleeves to present the prints in. For the stickers, I met with a local graphic printer (www.phatdigitaldesign.com) who specializes in stickers. We settled on creating stickers in both large (4-1/2"x 6") and small (2-1/2"x 1-3/4") sizes. The material is vinyl, two-ply, and UV resistant, making them great for indoor and outdoor use without fading or peeling.

Where is the Money Going?

The money from this campaign will go towards creating more (stickers and prints), website cost (SquareSpace), getting an LLC, and advertising on social media (Facebook, Instagram, Google).

If I am not able to generate the full $3,000...Knock on wood...I am willing to scale down on quantity of products and brand build-up until I can reach this goal, but will not lower the level of quality.

Perks!

  • $5, $10, $20: For these donations you get the option to choose your perk by receiving a coupon that is equivalent to your donation (example) $5 donation equals $5 off coupon for a product from the www.LowerLegArt.com website. Products are currently available on the website for pre-order and products will be sent out in July.
  • $50: This tier will get you a 50% off coupon that can be used on the website, www.LowerLegArt.com and it will get you one raffle ticket to potentially win a “Let’s Face It” framed original.
  • $75: This tier will get you a 75% off coupon that can be used on the website, www.LowerLegArt.com and it will get you two raffle tickets to potentially win a “Let’s Face It” framed original.
  • $100: I have created an 8th face (dubbed, 'Special') to the "Let's Face It" collection. ONLY the people who donate to this campaign will be able to receive a copy of this face.
  • $150: This is a very special perk and there is only one available! This perk gets you the original, framed piece of the exclusive 8th face, 'Special'.
  • $200: Want to guarantee yourself an original framed "Let's Face It" piece? Get this perk! There are only three available pieces for this slot, make sure to email me your preference and I will do my best to accommodate.
  • $500: This perk wraps together all the perks! It includes a $20 coupon, an exclusive 8th face print of 'Special', an original framed "Let's Face It" piece, and an original oil painting, "Time (is) Timmy".

 

**Raffle Ticket: Three people will receive an original “Let’s Face It” framed piece that are not in the $200 tier. It doesn’t matter which tier you bought into, it just matters which raffle tickets are selected.

**International Shipping: If you are located outside of the United States and interested in a perk that involves shipping, please email (lowerlegart@gmail.com) Then, we can figure out how much shipping will cost depending on where you are located. 

The Future?

Once the products are created and the website is fully up and running, I plan to keep making more art that will be printed onto stickers and prints. I want to move into making t-shirts. For summer 2019 my goal is to travel around to festivals as a full-time vendor.

Other Ways You Can Help

SHARE, FOLLOW, SHARE, FOLLOW, SHARE

If you are not able to donate, please share this campaign on social media!

AND

If you like what you see, please take a moment to follow Lower Leg on Instagram (@lowerleg) and Facebook (@LowerLegArt).

 

Thank You!

story:
HALA FiX – A New Chapter for our community

We’re building Romania’s biggest independent theatre and we need your help. After five years of existence, Teatru FiX wants to start a new chapter and lays the foundation of a contemporary art venue. HALA FiX is located on the premises of a former industrial centre in Iasi – Moldomobila – and has a complete surface of 1600 square meters.

So far, we’ve invested more than 70,000 dollars in the partitioning of the building alone. This included building new walls, installing fire proof access doors, concrete screed and other construction works. Moreover, between the 21st and 23rd of October, with the help of our friends from Hubrica, we hosted the third episode of the Gathering event. In short, about 50 graffers, architects, visual artists and musicians organised an indoor intervention in our venue, giving a whole new look to the former industrial space.

Unfortunately, our financial means have worn thinner and thinner and we can no longer cope with the necessities of the venue. We want to create an independent art centre that could cluster and support the local artistic community, on one hand, and offer the local public the possibility to consume a wide and ever diverse array of artistic products, on the other. We wholeheartedly believe that art has the power to regenerate a community and we would like for this project to be the result of a collaborative effort between the artist and the community.

 

Who are we?

Since 2012, Teatru FiX is the only independent theatre in Iasi. In our five years of activity, we’ve independently produced 13 plays and we participated in numerous independent theatre festivals, both national and international. We have also hosted tens of independent productions, various workshops and concerts and over 14,000 people experienced Teatru FiX firsthand.

Our team grew and strengthened in the past five years and it currently numbers about ten people, not counting the volunteers who work with us and support us. At the same, we worked with more than 25 independent actors in Iasi, actors who remained in the FiX family.

 

We support independent artists, their work and ideas. Invest in us to invest in them!

 

What is our aim?

The purpose of the HALA FiX project is to contribute to the development of independent theatre and culture. We hope to achieve this purpose by creating a free expression art space for independent artists, inside the community and for the community.

Through our project we want to:

- develop a venue that is unique by size, location and use;

- revitalise an industrial area that’s currently of low interest for the community and turn it into a regenerative cultural core;

- bring independent national and international productions and artists to Iasi, with the possibility of reducing some of the costs through our own structures ( for example, accommodation and meal costs);

- develop a network of partners and collaborators with other independent structures across Romania, Europe and the USA;

- create and support a stable and self-sustainable local community of independent artists.

 

Practically, as far as facilities and spatial partitioning are concerned, HALA FiX will have:

- two multifunctional black-box theatre rooms, of 150 and respectively 250 m2;

- a workplace for decor building;

- two workshop rooms;

- a coffee shop/ exhibition space of 150 m2;

- a 600 m2 concert hall;

- a closed circuit accommodation structure;

- a 150 m2 catering structure;

- a 160 m2 terrace.

 

Why and how could you help us?

For our team, everything that has been done so far represented a superhuman effort that channelled all of the resources we could find. For all that is about to be done, we need help. The project we bring forward is a bold one and it’s aimed at the community. Therefore, HALA FiX cannot become a reality without help from the community.

The total worth of the development project is more than 120,000 dollars and the main lines of investment and financing go towards:

- heating, thermal insulation and hydro insulation systems, that cost 44,674 dollars;

- truss and stage technique: first of all, we will be needing a truss for the lighting equipments, that should cover the entire space. Moreover, we will have to purchase wireless microphones, lanyard microphones and headsets that would ensure artists’ mobility on stage, when needed. Last but not least, we’ll be needing dimmers, cables and a lighting control panel. All in all, based on the offers we have received so far, this segment requires an investment of about 59,100 dollars.

- a professional sound system: a fully-equipped, professional sound system that would respond to the needs of our space, is worth about 17,700 dollars, according to the research we did.

￼

In spite of the numbers, winter is coming, so we decided to prioritize our needs and the most pressing one is to have a heated venue. So, if you believe in our project and you want to support us, you should know that we’re in urgent need of heating and insulation. A heating system as well as thermal and hydro insulation would allow us to use the space even in those times when the weather is rather unfriendly.

Thermal insulation entails the replacement of all the windows in the venue. The old structure is more than 40 years old and is made up of concrete grids and glass and many of the windows are broken. In order to thermally insulate the building, we need 30 panels of PVC joinery. The cost of a single panel varies from 257.35 dollars to 599.97 dollars, depending on dimension and placement. For a total surface of 225 m2, the overall costs of purchase and fitting go as high as 17,255 dollars.

Hydro-insulation is pretty similar, in terms of technicalities. At the moment, the ceiling is covered with glass fibre and metal structures that are decades old. They were, of course, affected by the passage of time and by the fact that the space hasn’t been used in more than 10 years. Consequently, rain, wind and snow often make their presence felt indoors as well. In order to solve this problem, 400 square meters of glass fiber panels will have to be replaced with hydro-insulating panels. A single square meter of such panels costs 18.32 dollars. Therefore, a system that would ensure complete insulation from bad weather and water infiltrations is around 7328 dollars.

Additionally, since our space will be hosting a variety of events that require a good sound quality, it needs to be phonically insulated. The system we are considering consists of layers of thick fabric disposed around the ceiling that would ensure a better dispersion of the sound and that would eliminate the echo effect of such a large venue. For one of the theatre rooms and the event hall, phonic insulation costs around 2363.70 dollars, including effective cost of materials and fitting.

Last but not least, given the dimensions of HALA FiX and the fact that the winter is getting closer and closer, a heating structure is absolutely vital to us. We want to opt for high-power fans with a thermal capacity over 300 kW. We’re still in the projection phase but we estimate that the cost of the necessary materials and equipments is at least 17727.75 dollars.

In short,we have great plans for HALA FiX. We want it to be rain-free and cold-free and we can’t do that without your help! We made the first step in this direction by bringing to HALA FiX more than 300 people who wholeheartedly answered our call. They supported us in filming the first episode of our story and you could support us in making the entire series.

 

WE HAVE THE CROWD! WE NEED THE FUNDING!

 

Descrierea in limba romana este disponibila aici.

story:
Short Summary and the Impact

My name is Kay HE. I am a composer. I am a video artist. I am a pianist. I am a photographer. I am a painter. I am a teacher. I am a new-fashioned Chinese. I am a free thinker. And oh yes, I am a woman. Being female is one of the last things I have thought about regarding my identity as an artist or as a person in general. As a female composer and multimedia artist, it’s been challenging to follow my dream without influenced by the subconscious judgments the society brought into my life. I have to fight harder to have my ideas heard. I have to work harder to get my music performed.

We all know the fact, in many fields; woman artists who were undoubtedly great are painfully underappreciated. But I am still going to restate the example: in classical concert music, where less than 2% of the artists programed by mainstream organizations are women. 2%!! This is why we started the TURN UP Multimedia Festival.

TURN UP festival is a woman-centered, artist-led, culture-connecting, multimedia festival turning up the volume for woman artist in traditional and electronic/digital media. We are trying to bring female artists from different field together in Austin area and create high-quality multimedia concerts that serve the community. We will TURN UP the visibility of Women Artists.

 

What We Need & What You Get

To produce a concert is never easy, to produce a multimedia concert is even harder. If you would like to support woman artists and their works please consider a donation to TURN UP Multimedia Festival.

Our first concert will take place in Homer Rainey Hall (Jessen Auditorium), Austin, TX on April 14th 7:30 pm.  (FREE admission, suggested donation $15)

You contribution will pay for our audio technicians who help us to run the equipment; will pay the talented performers; will pay the creativities of the awesome composers, will pay the innovations of our brilliant visual artists. I don’t like to see artists work for free or get underpaid for their hard work. But, because we just launched this festival, we will need help from the community, WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Here is our draft budget:

Venue: in-kind donation from UT Austin

Audio equipment: in-kind donation from UT Austin

Audio technicians: $200

Video/audio Recording: $300

BMI/ASCAP License (composers): $300

Performers (in-kind but prefer to pay for their work): $400

Video artists (in-kind but prefer to pay for their work): $240

Administrative Staff (in-kind but prefer to pay for their work): $160

Reception $200

Promotional material (posters, programs, information sheets) $200

Total: $2000

This is our idea budget for this concert, we will try to reach our goal, but if we couldn’t reach the entire goal. We will make sure the audio technician, videographer, and performers get paid for their hard work!

Unique Perks:

$10 perks: unique TURN UP poster

$25 perks: TURN UP keychain

$50 perks: TURN UP mug or TURN UP T-shirt.

$100 perks: best seat in the concert hall that provides the best audiovisual experience and a TURN UP   mug or T-shirt (can be personalized just for you).

 

Other Ways You Can Help

May be you are a poor artist that can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please use Indiegogo share tool to spread the words for us!

Make some noise about our campaign on Facebook!

Get your community involved!

Just simply come to the concert and cheer for the amazing woman artists!
story_txt:
Short Summary and the Impact
My name is Kay HE. I am a composer. I am a video artist. I am a pianist. I am a photographer. I am a painter. I am a teacher. I am a new-fashioned Chinese. I am a free thinker. And oh yes, I am a woman. Being female is one of the last things I have thought about regarding my identity as an artist or as a person in general. As a female composer and multimedia artist, it’s been challenging to follow my dream without influenced by the subconscious judgments the society brought into my life. I have to fight harder to have my ideas heard. I have to work harder to get my music performed.
We all know the fact, in many fields; woman artists who were undoubtedly great are painfully underappreciated. But I am still going to restate the example: in classical concert music, where less than 2% of the artists programed by mainstream organizations are women. 2%!! This is why we started the TURN UP Multimedia Festival.
TURN UP festival is a woman-centered, artist-led, culture-connecting, multimedia festival turning up the volume for woman artist in traditional and electronic/digital media. We are trying to bring female artists from different field together in Austin area and create high-quality multimedia concerts that serve the community. We will TURN UP the visibility of Women Artists.
 
What We Need & What You Get
To produce a concert is never easy, to produce a multimedia concert is even harder. If you would like to support woman artists and their works please consider a donation to TURN UP Multimedia Festival.
Our first concert will take place in Homer Rainey Hall (Jessen Auditorium), Austin, TX on April 14th 7:30 pm.  (FREE admission, suggested donation $15)
You contribution will pay for our audio technicians who help us to run the equipment; will pay the talented performers; will pay the creativities of the awesome composers, will pay the innovations of our brilliant visual artists. I don’t like to see artists work for free or get underpaid for their hard work. But, because we just launched this festival, we will need help from the community, WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Venue: in-kind donation from UT Austin
Audio equipment: in-kind donation from UT Austin
Audio technicians: $200

Performers (in-kind but prefer to pay for their work): $400

Reception $200

Total: $2000
This is our idea budget for this concert, we will try to reach our goal, but if we couldn’t reach the entire goal. We will make sure the audio technician, videographer, and performers get paid for their hard work!

$10 perks: unique TURN UP poster
$25 perks: TURN UP keychain
$50 perks: TURN UP mug or TURN UP T-shirt.
$100 perks: best seat in the concert hall that provides the best audiovisual experience and a TURN UP   mug or T-shirt (can be personalized just for you).
 
Other Ways You Can Help

story:
I dream of a day when Muslims and Jews can embrace one another with a hug and not fear getting blown to hell. Where blacks and whites in America can blend together into a beautiful grey. A world where the Western world can appreciate the uniqueness of the East. A day where a Westboro Bapist would genuinely endorse a homosexual's wedding vows.............. Yes maybe I am delusional but the current reality of this world I live in is extremely hateful and it honestly just plain sucks............. Hear me out.................

Hello All

My name is Eric. I just finished a novel. I did not write it with ink but rather my blood, sweat and tears. It took several years to bring this idea from conception to where it is today. It spanned over a period of my life that involved drug addiction, suicide attempts, depression, lost faith, a few months of homelessness, world travel(Egypt and China), and many broken(some restored) relationships. Needless to say this book was written by someone with a "unique" perspective on the world. I wish to share my ideas with you in the form of an other worldly fantasy novel. Imagine George Lucas, C.S. Lewis and JRR Tolkien had a threesome............ that is the type of world I have attempted to create(Not their threesome but rather the byproduct of those 3 great minds coming together). 

This book can be read on a very deep level with lots of metaphors but I feel a child's imagination would also enjoy the world I have created.

My visual artist is from Egypt. I met her on my travels. She is currently enrolled in art college. She will be illustrating the novel and her home country of Egypt will be receiving some of the profit of the book's sales(to go to an orphanage in Egypt).

I am also a musician and plan on putting together a soundtrack/score for the book. I have put together a collaboration of professional producers, engineers and musicians, we are just waiting on funding. The recordings will be done once the final editing is done for the novel. We will release the music online after the book's release if the music requires that much time to produce.

My book is finished. I just need the $1,500 to pay for professional editing(Top notch quality editing). I am asking for $2,900 because IndieGoGo's taxes about %50. I even got my Grandpa Lee to throw in $300 to help with publishing.............. don't let down Grandpa Lee


Thank you all

Will you dream with me?

story:
I have liaised with a book publishing company who has been kind enough to provide advice and support on the steps I need to take and the funds required in order to put together a book detailing the culture of gaming tattoos.

I created the instagram page in March 2014, it was my ambiton to bring together a community of dedicated gamers and amazing artists by sharing work by people from all over the world.

I've been lucky enough to be featured in a few gaming magazines, and now I would love to move on the possibility of a book!

In addition, more than 50 artists and tattoo artists from all over the world including the UK, Australia and the US have donated perks such as prints, orginal art pieces and even tattoo time to make help make the book happen, so if you are passionate about the gaming and tattoo community, be sure to check the campaign out and even donate if you can, its a chance to get tattooed by loads of amazing artists and have a piece featured in a book at the same time!

As an example, a 256 page book, glossy art paper, hardcover would be approximately (could be slightly more/less):

1000 books = $16,000 including layout/design or $16.00 per book
2000 books = $20,000 including layout/design or $10.00 per book

The variables in this situation are actual page count of the book, size of the book (8.5x11, 10x13, 8x10)

For more artist info, check out the updates tab or head over to instagram and find videogametatts 

I would be honoured if you would make a contribution to this project,

Thanks again,

Regards, Alex

videogametatts

AS YOU ALL ARE AWARE THE PROJECT IS SET AS FLEXIBLE FUNDING, HOWEVER ALL PROCEEDS WILL STILL BE INVESTED INTO FUNDING THE BOOK AND EVERYONE WHO HAS CONTRIBUTED FOR PERKS WILL STILL RECEIVE WHAT THEY HAVE DONATED FOR =)

story:
WHO ARE WE?

 The Wulfden is a collective dedicated to incubating new work and providing a platform for emerging voices. We provide safe spaces and resources for artists to do what they do best: create

As members of a generation where privacy has been made public, our aim is to expose the truths hidden in the everyday by working across mediums, in found spaces, and amongst our community.

Our work is unapologetic. Our work is experiential. It is both intimate and uncomfortable. The Wulfden invites you, the audience, to fall into the unknown with us, challenge us, and explore the intricacies of our shared human experience. 

WHAT IS ZIPPED & PELTED?

This world premiere play by Lucas Baisch, directed by Katrina Dion, will take place during the 2015 Chicago Fringe Festival. Zipped and Pelted is an absurdist take on the world’s stigmatized views of the identity-bending furry community. Using the violent events of last year’s Midwest Furfest as a framing device, the play combines kitsch and convention culture and Internet message boards to explore a community that actively investigates what it means to be animal.

We have been lucky to be given one of the biggest spaces during the festival, so we need you to make sure we can provide every audience member with a fruitful theatrical experience.

WHERE WILL THE MONEY GO?

1.  Paying all of our artists. Every single one.

2.  Fursuits for every actor and other costume needs.

3.  Funding for a set that is both aesthetically engaging and transportable.

4.  Funding for original sound and lighting design.

5.  Marketing materials including a poster, trailer, new company website and company logo!

6.  Helping to secure our performance space costs.

7.  Miscellaneous needs such as a rental truck and printing materials.

Yes, we can do all of that with just $4000 dollars. How does that all break down?  

WHY SHOULD YOU DONATE?

Donating to The Wulfden’s production of Zipped & Pelted would be supporting a new play, created by young artists, who with just a little bit of money want to create an engaging piece of theatrical storytelling that speaks to communities of all shapes and sizes.

The Wulfden is made up of an artistic ensemble who have proven their creative prowess in an assortment of unconventional spaces (attics, churches, apartments, etc.) Your support would help continue the career of artists who are determined to pay it forward, engage civically with their work and the community, and foster opportunities for outside artists. By supporting The Wulfden and Chicago Fringe, you will not only be directly helping this specific production, but contributing to the impact of Chicago Theater, utilizing art to provoke questions of the shared human experience. 

Zipped and Pelted will be performed at the Congregational Church of Jefferson Park Gym, 5320 W Giddings St, on:

September 5, 5:30pm

September 7, 8:30pm

September 11, 8:30pm

September 12, 2:30pm

September 13, 7:00pm


Production Team:

Director: Katrina Dion*

Stage Manager: Clarissa Jugo

Production Manager: Julia Buckton

Scenic Design: Greg Pinsoneault

Costume Design: Catharine Young

Lighting Design: Emmaleigh Pepe-Winshell

Sound Design: Connor Ciesil

Dramaturg: Carina Abbaticchio

Assistant Director: Michael Conroy

Casting Director: Jared Hecht*


Cast:

Boomer: Dominique Watkins

Mikey: Jaboukie Young-White

Worm: Sydney Germaine

Izzy: Asia Martin

Don Featherstone: Rejinal Simon

Ensemble: Rachel Rosen, Tim Maher

*Denotes Wulfden Ensemble


                                                        We hope to see you there!

story:
The Temple of Sound received an honorarium art grant from Burning Man and our team is now reaching out to you to assist in supporting the final stages of building this giant ambient musical instrument.  

Inspired from the ancient Irish tradition of the Aeolian Harp, the Temple of Sound was designed by Darren Fitzpatrick a previous member of the International Arts Megacrew in 2011, residing in Dublin, Ireland. 

We have two other members from the International Arts Megacrew with Lightning Bolt Wonder aka LB & Athena whom met on playa in 2005 and were married in 2011 at the Temple of Transition. Along with a 14 year veteran, whom will be working on his first build on playa. A 3rd year burner also on his first team build and 3 virgins whom will be learning all about the Burning Man community and how we build large scale art installations.  

We thank you for your support, for without it we would not be able to produce this beautiful sound installation.  We hope that you are excited about seeing the Temple of Sound come to reality and if you know anyone whom might be interested to please share our Indiegogo campaign with them.

Namaste. 

The Temple of Sound Crew.

story:
We are a community of artists and social activists, and we are launching a campaign to save HOME 45 - a unique art union in Armenia located in a historical building in the centre of Yerevan.

Home 45 is a free public space, located in the cellar of a building, constructed in the end of the 19th century on Yeznik Koghbatsi Street – one of the four streets making up the Old Yerevan district. Formally the buildings are under the protection of the government, but in reality they are being deconstructed one by one; the few ones that survived are expecting their death sentence. 

Last year we were struggling to preserve another significant building, the Afrikians Club. Although it was eventually deconstructed, the campaign for the protection of the building formed a strong community of artists, scientists, social activists, journalists and researchers, who are working hard for the protection and actualization of the historical heritage.

By supporting Home 45 you will help this historical building to get a chance to survive and live a longer life, to serve creative people from Armenia and all over the world.

Home 45 was created with the means and enthusiasm of this community: a dirty rotten cellar step by step turned into a bright and light hearted free public space for social activism. It opened this spring and has hosted more than 50 travellers from all over the world, dozens of exhibitions, workshops, performances and even the most innovative wedding in Yerevan. The space is open to everyone who needs a space to create.

The platform has been supported by our community and from the small donations of our guests and residents, however, it is getting harder and harder to pay the rent and communal expenses.  We initiated several fundraising events, and managed to collect a small amount of money, only letting us cover one month rent. Meanwhile, the space needs renovation, basic furnishing, and wireless connection to become more useful for the artists, researchers and all the creative people. 

And finally, a very natural detail: as most life forms, artists also need to shit and pee. There’s a shit-pit of common use outside in the yard, serving to home 45 and 3 neighbouring houses. Thanks God, all the bars and cafes in the area belong to our friends, and we can use their toilets freely…  But our own toilet and bathroom would make the life of the whole neighbourhood more comfortable. 

We need to raise USD 3, 500 to do the following things:

  1. To construct toilet and bathroom,
  2. To renovate the space and buy some basic furniture,
  3. To pay the rent for the upcoming 6 months,
  4. To install a wireless connection.

story:
Artists struggle. We make due with whatever we can to pursue the dream of being full time creators. 

For me the act of creating art literally consumes my life. When I am not creating, I am seeking to teach. I freely offer my assistance to any artist who needs help. I share techniques and ideas whenever possible. I mentor artists around the world via the various social networks across the internet. 

I also allow interns to study in my studio free of charge, offering supplies and training to underprivileged artists who may not have another chance to thrive.

But without the proper equipment much of this comes to an abrupt halt. 

The image above is the last image created using severely outdated equipment that has long surpassed its life expectancy.  There will be no more

On a beautiful summer morning, awaiting the arrival of students, my desktop finally bit the dust. With a dying purr and a sad little whimper, the computer that allows me to function daily in all activities including the creation of digital art vanished. 

Let me tell you about the image on this page. This is not a digital image alone. This was created by body painting and posing a model first in a 5 hour art session and then working with the final photos to create the image. 

But without the proper equipment this studio becomes only a quarter of what it was and should be. My ability to help others, my ability to create some forms of art such as the photo above, and my sanity, is pretty much gone. 

So this pleading artist is asking for your help to fund a new desktop computer for his studio and the proper software packages needed to run the studios daily operations. 

In exchange for this help I have created an array of pretty amazing perks. I hope they interest you.

World famous author Poppy Z Brite is going to give away a copy of his new short story compilation "The Little Purple Book" with each donation of $200.00 and above. So one more added awesome perk to help get this campaign really moving! 

Creatively,

~Grey~

story:
About the Show

Hi! My name is Hillary Eustis and I am currently a Master of Arts Administration candidate at the Savannah College of Art and Design. To complete my degree, I am planning, curating, fundraising, and marketing a group exhibition, Functional Creations, in Savannah, Georgia.

The purpose of this exhibition is to showcase “functional creations” (i.e. handbags, pillows, bowls, mugs, etc.) by fiber and ceramic artists and give both established and emerging artists the opportunity to share their work. Often, people tend to group these types of works in with ‘crafts’ and forget that these creations can also be works of art. I am putting together an exhibition that highlights artists who dedicate their time and talent to creating functional items that hold as much artistic value as an oil painting on canvas.

The opening reception will give visitors to the exhibition the opportunity to socialize and experience these works of art in a relaxed and inviting setting and engage with some of the local artists included in the show.

The exhibition will run from August 12, 2015 – August 15, 2015 at Sulfur Studios (2301 Bull St, Savannah, GA 31401) and the opening reception for the show will take place on Friday August 14th from 6 to 9 pm. 

What this exhibition needs & What we'll give you!

Functional Creations needs to raise a total of $1,200 to cover all costs and make this a successful show!

  • $500 covers the rental of Sulfur Studios for the show
  • $250 covers the cost of promotional materials to market the show to the public (postcards, flyers, stickers, and an exhibition catalog)
  • $250 covers the cost of food and beverage for the opening reception
  • $200 covers the cost of the rest of the exhibition materials, such as display material rentals, artwork labels, and window decals for the venue

In return for donating to my project, you will receive the following perks –

  • $5 Donation – A handwritten thank-you letter expressing my appreciation!
  • $10 Donation – $5 perk, plus a Functional Creations sticker
  • $20 Donation – All $10 perks, plus an exhibition postcard
  • $50 Donation – All $20 perks (sticker, thank you, and postcard), plus a signed exhibition poster
  • $100 Donation – All $50 perks, plus a tour through the exhibition led by me, the curator. (8 available)
  • $250 Donation – All $100 perks, and your name featured in the exhibition catalog as a sponsor of the exhibition. (5 available)

If I am unable to reach my funding goal, I will use what funds I have raised to cover the venue rental costs and necessary exhibition material expenses to ensure that the show still goes up.

Your contribution will greatly assist in making this exhibition successful, not only for me, but also for the artists who have submitted their wonderful works of art to the show.

If you are unable to donate at this time, there are still some ways you can help support my project:

  • Promote the event by sharing with all your friends on Facebook, and encouraging them to support the exhibition at https://www.facebook.com/events/1634642123440103/
  • Attend the opening reception on Friday August 14th from 6 to 9 pm, or visit the show anytime from August 12th to the 15th. (The show will be open to the public daily from 11am to 5 pm.)

story:
The Basics

The Great Scottish Make Off is an idea for a fun, engaging arts event to take place across several cities in Scotland in summer 2016. The aim is to bring together communities, artists, and local organisations to make something that everyone can enjoy.

Think of it as a real life, much less competitive, more interactive version of your favourite reality cooking competition, but with no losers. We’re just replacing food with art…and we’re not cooking it. We will not be held responsible for what happens if you put your paints on the hob or a sculpture in the oven.

There are three core parts of the idea:

Competition Bit

In each city, a group of artists* will be selected and given a brief, materials, and one day to create a piece.

*We say artist for ease of use on words, but anyone can apply to be one of the competitors. If you aren’t a professional artist or maker, but want to show your work, you are more than welcome to apply. All are welcome, though space will be limited.

Interactive Bit

If you like Master Chef or Bake Off, watching is half the fun, but by the end of an episode you’ve got your stand mixer out and flour all over half the kitchen. We want to make sure everyone is involved and gets to try a little creativity. We’ll run workshops with local artists, and even have mini make-off challenges for everyone to try.

Exhibition Bit

Under pressure, sometimes things can be completely different than what you would make at home (for better or worse). The selected artists will also get a chance to exhibit the body of work they would normally show in a gallery or art festival. So the public can see the artist making under these restrictions, but also see what he or she would normally make in the comfort of his or her own studio.

BUT WAIT, there’s more… There will be parties, music, local businesses and organisations, fun experiements for kids, adventures for grown ups, and so much more. 

Also, we just finished a rough trial run in Edinburgh where we were able to learn a LOT about what we'll need to do to scale this project up and improve it. Check out more about it here.

The Impact aka Why should I care?

There’s a lot of great art going on in Scotland. We’re really proud of that, but universally there’s a preceived divide between the “art world” and “non-arty” people. The Great Scottish Make Off is a bridge between these groups by making a unique, accessible opportunity that encourages everyone to experience the benefits of creativity*. 

People can come for some music and drinks in the evening, or bring their kids to try something new during the day, or just watch what happens in true reality TV style, but we’ll making sure anyone can join in.

*What benefits are these you might ask? Employees with a creative outlet perform better, students who participate in the arts achieve better grades, people with illnesses who participate in the arts can actually get better faster (We’re not making this up! We’ve done research. There's some of it here, here, here, here, and here). 

A Bit More in Depth

Where will this happen?

  • Paisley
  • Inverness
  • Aberdeen
  • Dundee
  • Edinburgh

These are our initial plans, but we are open to working with additional communities or changing locations slightly. Plus, this is the first event, as we grow we can show up in more places.

We plan to launch in Paisley for a week of fun and making at the end of July. We’re excited about Paisley and Renfrewshire as it goes for city of culture 2021 and it’s just a few minutes on the bus or train from Glasgow city centre.

We’ll then spend a long weekend each in Inverness, Aberdeen, and Dundee.

Finally, we’ll land in Edinburgh during the Festival season with the fruits of our labours from the other cities. We’ll exhibit the work made in the other cities and let Edinburgh have a chance to get in on the fun as well.

When will this happen?
End of July - August 2016, We haven't locked in any firm days. We know we want to finish by bringing all of the work and energy to Edinburgh during the festival season, and we know this will take a year to plan to perfection.

The Edinburgh Festival(s)

The festival season in Edinburgh is roughly the month of August and the population of Scotland’s capital quadruples with visitors from all over the world. We think this is a great way to finish the make off. With the smaller budget, we will run for just over a week. This portion of the Make Off will include:

  • the same core bits of make off discussed above
  • exhibition of the work made in other cities
  • ticketed evening parties and performances
  • special collaborations with visiting performers and artists

In spite of the fact that the 2015 festival just ended, we already need to lock in our venue for next year. If we can raise enough funding, we’ll go for the whole month. It’s part of our big budget plan. We’re being realistic to start and planning for a week.

What We Need & What You Get

In this campaign we're trying to raise £35,000, which will get us started and guarantee the project can run. For the full scale project, we'll need a minimum of £100,000. We are applying for funding from other sources, but what will help our application is a groundswell of public support and a strong initial investment from the community.

There are also some great perks available so you can go ahead and be part of 

There are the vitally important things we can't get around paying for: 

  • Licenses from the councils in each city
  • Several types of insurance (for the art, the venue, the volunteers)
  • Venues in each city (funny how you need a place to go)
  • Exhibition equipment (we can’t just lean that painting against the wall), 
  • Materials for the artists and workshops
  • Staff (we’ve done everything with just volunteers, but on a project of this scale we’ll need a minimum of one full time staff member to manage the project, a a part timer in each city starting a few months before)
  • Shipping/transport of work (it unfortunately can't teleport to Edinburgh)
  • Publicity (though hopefully we'll get a lot of traction from social media, we'll still need to print up posters, place a few ads, have a sign on the venue so people know where to go, even the web design)
  • Planning costs (While coffee shops are great, we'll even need to pay for places to have meetings, we'll need paper, pens, a good accountant, and a little bit of legal work)

Getting into the Awesome

There are a lot of little things we haven't mentioned. We plan to live stream part of the making process, create a great video of everything, be all over social media with it, and create a catalogue with the art that's made and images of the process. There are more ideas bubbling and we'll be developing them with the local teams we assemble.

Risks & Challenges

There are a lot of things that can go wrong when you're organising people, an artist might cancel last minute, something might go wrong with the venue, a giant sea monster might swallow all of Scotland, but on some of these, we can do something about it.

Most of this comes down to people and planning. We are making a clear plan, building a team with the right skills and putting in place checks and balances to make sure things get done when they are supposed to. Obviously, we'll have to rely a lot on volunteers, so having a devoted team is key and a few core staff members who can follow up and ensure everything is done right.

Other Ways You Can Help

After you’ve donated, SHARE SHARE SHARE. There are even handy Indiegogo share buttons for all your social media! we need 3,500 people to each give £10 to hit our initial goal. 

Also: Get involved! We want to make sure your community gets the best project possible. So come volunteer, tell us what you want, tell us about great venues, if you have a skill you think we could use or an idea that would make the project even more amazing, we want you involved so talk to us, sign up for the mailing list, and come along to our planning and community engagement meetings that we'll be organising in the next few weeks.

Who are you anyway? ...You sound awfully American in that video

We’re Pop Up! Scotland, a social enterprise (legal stuff: we’re incorporated as an asset locked community interest company…that basically means any money we do make has to go back into the community and community projects). A bit more about our organisation: we launched in July 2014 and have already been selected for a number of awards, including: Santander Entrepreneurship Residency at the University of Edinburgh 2014, Social Enterprise Award in the Converge Challenge 2014, finalist for LaunchMe social enterprise startup 2015, InCube Renfrewshire 2015-2016, and the Social Innovation Incubation Award 2015.

In the video is Anne, our Creative Director. She might be from the US, but she’s lived in Edinburgh for four years and is really passionate about the arts in Scotland. She devotes 90% of her time to Pop Up! projects and 10% to swing dancing. Sleeping and eating happen occasionally. No, she’s not getting paid for this.

The rest of our core team includes Frida and Zoe.

Frida started volunteering with us when Anne ran her first pop up event and has stuck around to keep helping. She’s is in charge of developing our workshop plans while being a full time mum to 10 month old Elsa. 

Zoe is in charge of our community outreach. She was a long time volunteer at North Edinburgh Arts before joining up with Anne and Frida and in between work and uni helps us plan ways to engage even more people in creative opportunities, especially those groups that lack cultural access.

In addition to the core, we have amazing volunteers who have come in for individual projects or worked with us behind the scenes as we’ve applied for funding and support throughout the process. There’s a lot so we’re bound to leave someone out, but we have to highlight Sarah our “intern”, Agne our interior architect, Jerry all around build it man and electrical engineer, Lenka who has swooped in to help organise when we were in dire straights, Ray our music man and fixer, Martyn our engineer and transport chief, plus so many others: Maro, Desi, Amelia (and more!)

story:
About Zooplankton

Zooplankton is an ambitious first build project by a tiny team of Portland burners, led by Becca Priddy, the creator of the project, and Sarah Erratica, her trusty sidekick and Co-Lead. This is the first time that either of them has attempted to plan, design, and create an art installation completely from scratch, and it has been an amazing journey full of hard lessons, surprises both welcome and unwelcome, and buckets of sweat and stubborn determination to make it all happen no matter the odds.

We have already constructed a space for learning, for interactivity, for contemplation and interaction, for shelter from the sun, shelter from your own troubles, and for any offerings that our visitors want to leave to be purged in the flames of our burn. Now, the only thing left is to get it to the playa. We have brought pieces of Zooplankton to SOAK and Critical Northwest, and now, with your help it is time for Zooplankton's final journey to Burning Man.

Our vision for Zooplankton is to bring people together in a space where art and science blend into one, where we share our creative visions with people from around the world, and share our knowledge of science and our hard work and passion for creating. 

Zooplankton is a 20 foot tall art installation based on a 19th century illustration by Ernst Haeckel of the skeleton of a microscopic marine radiolaria, Calocyclas monumentum. During the day Zooplankton will be a lecture hall where guests from the community will hold classes and workshops on science and art, as well as a shady space to relax and a place to leave offerings and tributes to be burned when our structure is set alight on Thursday night. By night the over 100 acrylic spikes that sprout from the skin of Zooplankton will be illuminated in a dazzling, glowing bioluminescent spectacle. Our programmer, Tony, has also developed a connector to a thermal camera that will be placed inside Zooplankton, so that the more people are inside the structure the more active the lights will become.


What We Need

1. Wood and supplies to complete the structure and spare parts in case of on-playa breakage - $1000
2. Transportation & fuel - $2700
3. Decomposed Granite for the Burn Pad - $700
4. Fuel for on playa power, wiring, special effects and pyrotechnics - $1000 
5. Wiring and Power supplies for LED spikes - $600

What your donation will provide

  •   A unique, handmade interactive art installation that will bring together science and art, including science lectures and a shady space during the day, and an interactive light display at night
  •   Lumber and supplies to complete the final parts of the installation and maintain/repair the installation on playa
  •   Industrial ground screws to keep Zooplankton secure and anchored to the playa
  •   Truck rental and fuel to get Zooplankton to the playa
  •   An Arduino to control the interactive light displays
  •   Generator and fuel to power the interactive light display
  •   Infrared camera for nighttime interactivity
  •   Supplies for creating an awesome burn on Thursday night, as well as the granite for the burn bed so the playa doesn't get damaged
 


)*( You want to see art built and burn don't you???

Zooplankton has been created from our imagination as a project for the community by the community. This bizarre, beautiful, wonky creature is our gift to you, all of you who will share space with us on the playa this year. We are the largest art installation coming from Portland, Oregon this year, Zooplankton has already been built and we cannot make it to Burning Man without your help. Thank you so much for your support.

story:
A Bold Interactive Multi Arts Street Festival

On July 11th, 2015 thousands of visitors will flood the streets of downtown Huntsville for a Free fun filled evening of interactive art, and performances in unconventional places presented by Edge of the Woods Theatre and Huntsville Festival of the Arts.  Now entering its 5th year, NbN has presented the work of over 500 local and invited artists and engaged tens of thousands of  community members in hands on art making activities and one of a kind artistic experiences.

And it's all FREE!

And we want to keep it that way. Our event survives on government funds, donations and the blood, sweat and tears of so many volunteers, artists and organizers. NbN has become a vital part of Muskoka's cultural fabric by using art to strengthen connections between the everyday lives of our attendees and the place they live, promoting increased community and civic engagement and supporting local small businesses in rural townships.

How Can You Help?

In honor of our fifth anniversary, we are asking our friends to give birthday presents of $25, $50 or $100. All funds will go directly to paying local artists. If you've attended before, or are planning on attending this year, or if you just believe in what we stand for, please consider supporting us.

Why Support Nuit Blanche North?

It Supports Artists.  In 2014, 106 different artists participated (up from 94 in 2013) presenting their work to over 7,000 attendees (up 40% from 2012) offering artists the opportunity to push the boundaries of their practice, and engage in potent creative collaborations with other artists, community members and the spaces around them. 

It Promotes the Arts. Art is for everyone. In order to reach as diverse an audience as possible, we strive to keep the event accessible. By presenting artistic activities in public spaces, we can better attract audiences who don’t traditionally attend arts events, and through that encounter, create fun and meaningful artistic experiences that leave leave a lasting effect.

Positive Economic Impact.  Through our event, we strive to bring increased opportunities to local businesses, showcasing the downtown core of Huntsville and building on Muskoka’s reputation as a tourism destination. 

Every year we face many challenges and financial uncertainties.

But we do it because we love it. And there are thousands who love it too, from youth to seniors, permanent residents to visitors, different cultures, races, abilities. Your donation will help all of us, and in turn make a powerful statement on the importance of this event. You gift will help us build support to keep Nuit Blanche North running for years to come!


Other Ways You Can Help

Hey -- We're artists and we TOTALLY understand if you are not able to  make a contribution, but if you like what you see here, then spreading the word about Nuit Blanche North is just as helpful for us! Sharing our campaign with your friends and family goes a long way -- or just find us on your favorite social media and give us a "like".

story:
Short Summary

The High Desert Mural Festival will take place in Pueblo, Colorado on October 2nd - 11th. It will be held throughout Pueblo's creative corridor and showcase the creative art and talent from artists coast-to-coast and everywhere in between. 

As well as live art there will be numerous galleries, venues, local businesses, boutiques, and eateries to enjoy throughout the creative corridor. With NO admission cost the event is free and open to anyone who wishes to simply observe the arts or would like to participate via their respective medium. 


What We Need & What You Get

To break it down here's what we need to make things happen and how you'll be incentivized to help do so:

  • First and foremost we'll need to get these artists out here. Again they'll be from coast-to-coast and everywhere in between: flights, lodging, transportation, and daily resources such as paint, food, etc will ensure the week-long festival will always have someone contributing something. Those accommodations as well as daily expenses will account for roughly 70% of proposed $20K we're hoping to achieve. 
  • Many of these artists are world-renown and have become well-known in the art community due to their talents; a great opportunity to meet some truly unique, talented, and beautiful people.  
  • If we're unable to reach our proposed goal of $20k we're still going to be utilizing said funds in a 70/30 split - 70% of funds will go to artist/mural accommodations and 30% will go towards fulfilling incentives. 

The Impact

The impact of this proposed project is limitless. We're essentially setting the stepping-stones to revitalizing our creative corridor and ushering a new life into the surrounding area. Let's not call it a face-lift..but rather make-over. We want Pueblo to be the premier destination for not only murals but the art collective as a whole. 

  • Your contribution is vital because whether your're donating and/or just visiting it's going to contribute to the success of the festival. 
  • Having already completed a few large-scale murals at a grass-roots level we're extremely confident any and all further murals will only contribute to the over-all aesthetic and enhancements of what we're trying to achieve. 
  • If you've watched the video you've already seen examples of what we've accomplished.. your contribution, again whether through donation or attendance, is going to guarantee the success we're striving for. 

Risks & Challenges

It's hard to gauge specific "risks" with our mission. As we stated we'll be moving forward regardless with our finished funds, exercising our 70/30 split. But just Murphy's Law states, anything that can happen...

  • We're problem solvers. We're intuitive, clever, and we feel that whatever may happen to arise as an obstacle or issue we're more than capable of handling. 
  • The fact is if a problem arises, we'll have to solve it accordingly when/if it comes up.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just want to help out there's a donation for that! 

  • We'll be producing a video of the week long festival that includes credit(s) from those who have donated at our minimum level. 
  • Even if you just SHOW UP you've already helped contribute to the over-all success we're hoping the festival brings to the city of Pueblo. 

One way or the other we hope to see you in October!

story:
Who We Are

Led by artist-educator Jan Tichy, The Heat Light Water Cultural Project (HLWCP) is a team of artists, cultural producers, thinkers, activists, and community partners who value art, culture and science as conduits for restoration, empowerment and engagement in downtown Gary and its surrounding neighborhoods. Through a collaborative partnership with local and regional artists, community members and city officials, our goal is to help re-energize Gary!

Jan Tichy is a contemporary artist and educator working in video, sculpture, architecture, and photography. Born in Prague in 1974, Jan studied art in Israel before earning his MFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago where he is now Assistant Professor in the Department of Photography. He has created socially engaged art projects in Chicago and internationally. Project Cabrini Green, which you can view here: http://www.projectcabrinigreen.org is just one example of his keen ability to bridge art, science, and community together.

One of the collaborators is Dr. Jeffreen Hayes. Jeffreen, an artistic producer and curator, believes, like Jan, in the power of art, culture and science to empower communities in need. She is supporting HLWCP through her organization bridge/arts, which provides administrative support to artist and community-driven art projects.

The Heat Light Water Cultural Project collaborators share a collective experience of over 15 years of art interventions, curating, and community engagement.

The Name

The Heat Light Water Cultural Project takes its name from what is currently known as the General Services building. The building’s given name, when designed by architect George W. Maher, was the Gary Heat Light Water Co. Warehouse. Taking into consideration that heat, light and water are essential elements for life and basic services, we believe that art is also a basic service.

Why Gary

We understand ourselves as cultural facilitators and catalysts who take our direction from what the community actually wants.

As artists, we believe in working with the people of Gary to not only provide access to  the arts but to also help individuals and communities tap into their creativity. We view these workshops as a way to identify the culture that already lives in Gary and to activate what is already there. The HLWCP workshops are one way to acknowledge that beauty exists in different forms—in forms different from the ways we typically identify as beauty.

Gary is part of our Chicagoland community and a neighbor. In order to build community you have to share resources, take care of your neighbor, and build a network. We want to share our artistic resources and show Gary, and the world, the beauty we see and experience in the community.

Gary is our neighbor. In order to build community you have to share resources, take care of your neighbor, and build networks.

What We Are Doing

To begin our long term engagement, we will be facilitating artist-run workshops this summer and fall. We take a holistic approach to community-building. Everyone should have access to the art. The workshops will offer something for everyone, with a focus on specific age groups, as well as intergenerational arts programming.

Some of the artist workshops include:

Documentary photography

●  This workshop will encourage different ways of seeing while teaching the participants about the history of photography and how it has been used to document cities and communities

Waveguide Radio Workshop

●  Workshops will teach participants how to create technology to support the collection stories from their community

Story-Collecting

●  A program that collects stories from residents of Gary, particularly senior citizens, in order to create a public alternative archive of Gary’s history

We will offer these as well as traditional forms of art: drawing, painting, etc.

At the end of our first year of artist-run workshops, we will have a community-curated exhibition of all of the art created! The exhibition will be presented back to the community at Indiana University Northwest’s Gallery of Contemporary Art!

What We Need

To help us facilitate these artist-run workshops for the community, we now need your help to raise $7,500 to complete our first phase of supporting Gary and beginning its transformation through arts and culture. 

Your contribution will help us provide the following:

●  Free arts programming

●  Supplies and materials for the classes

●  Snacks and beverages for the participants

●  Teaching Artist fees

●  Administrative fees

●  Transportation

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to financially contribute to our campaign, please considering supporting the project by:

●  Sharing the work we are doing in Gary with your friends, family and peers.


Thank you for your support! Check back for updates about the workshops.

story:
A Mile in My Shoes, The Empathy Museum's first exhibition, has now closed its doors. Presented from 4th - 27th September as part of Totally Thames festival we received over 2,000 visitors and were featured live, in print and on-line as far afield as Brazil. Our shoe-box is now winging its way to its next festival - please sign up to our newsletter to find out where...

A huge thank you to all of our Indiegogo supporters for making this possible.

www.empathymuseum.com

ORIGNAL INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN:

We are an artist/producer team of Clare Patey and Kitty Ross. Working with philosopher and cultural thinker Roman Krznaric and based on ideas in his book Empathy we are creating the world’s first Empathy Museum. The Empathy Museum will be a touring experiential space dedicated to developing the skill of empathising.

A Mile in My Shoes

"You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view – until you climb into his skin and walk around in it,"  Atticus Finch in To Kill a Mockingbird, Harper Lee

This September our launch exhibit A Mile in My Shoes will open in London as part of the  Totally Thames festival. Taking the form of an interactive shoe shop on the banks of the Thames, visitors will be invited to literally walk a mile in someone else’s shoes whilst being immersed in an audio narrative of their life.

In association with In the Dark radio we are already collecting shoes and stories from local people, from a paediatric brain surgeon and market trader to a refugee and chess grand master. A Mile in My Shoes will be housed in a specially designed giant shoebox that we will create for the event.

A Mile in My Shoes will tour internationally in 2016 as part of the Empathy Museum, and we will be adding to our collection of shoes and stories as we go. We need your help to ensure that we can complete this work and take our vision for the Empathy Museum on the road. 

The idea of the Empathy Museum has already captured the public imagination, drawing media attention in the UK from the Independent to the BBC, and in countries such as Brazil, Italy and Croatia.


‘Empathy - the imaginative act of stepping into another person’s shoes and viewing the world from their perspective – is a radical tool for social change and should be a guiding light for the art of living.’ Roman Krznaric

What we need and What you get

We have secured the funding to create the content for our first exhibition A Mile in My Shoes. Now we need your help to create a playful, theatrical, mobile space to house this and future exhibits.

Working with a team of artists and designers we are planning to convert a shipping container into a state of the art exhibition space. The exterior will resemble a giant shoebox and the interior will display our collection with a space for visitors to share their experiences and contribute stories and a photo of their own shoes.

Your contribution will give us the £15,000 we need to complete our vision, launch the Empathy Museum and spread the empathy message.

Breakdown of the Budget

£5,000 - to buy and part convert a shipping container

£5,000- design, materials and build cost to transform the container into a mobile exhibition space  - the shoebox

£2,000 - for audio equipment

£3,000 - storage, transport and presentation of A Mile in My Shoes at new venues 

No contribution is too small – please join us in the empathy revolution!

Our perks are listed on the right hand side.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren’t able to donate there are other ways you can help!

Please share our video and message on social media.

Come and see A Mile in My Shoes in London in September or on tour in 2016

story:
The power of imagination and positive fantasizing does wonders to help the sick recover! That is exactly the kind of impact I'd like my art to have, and in this pursuit I created two detailed, dreamy digital artworks that I intend to print and hang as life-sized artworks in NYC's Ronald McDonald House (http://www.rmhc.org/about-us).  


Who I am:

I am a Brooklyn-based artist working to spread a positive impact through my work, to make people smile, dream, and think. The themes that continuously inspire me and the themes that I try to convey in my art are of nature, interdependence, cooperation, creation, hope and preservation. My work can be found on my website: www.apocalisseart.com

What this is:

The Ronald McDonald House provides a warm and welcoming temporary home to families so that they can stay near a hospitalized child in NYC. These children spend a lot of quality time relaxing with their families within this space. The RMH has many artworks decorating its walls, but few made specifically for kids. "Tree of Life" and "Mermaid World" were inspired by the kinds of worlds children like to imagine exploring - space and the ocean. They are designed to stimulate their imaginations, inspire them to reflect on the meaning and purpose of a being in its environment, and to transport them to lively, colorful worlds, generating hope within them and taking their minds off of pain and stress.

Here they are: 
"Tree of Life" (to be printed at 40" x 60")

"Mermaid World" (to be printed at 30" x 50")

I've worked on these drawings for about 6 months, but they are just the preliminary images. They need to be retouched, edited for large canvases, and sent to the printers before they can help provide a dreamy and healing environment in the Ronald McDonald House. With your support, I can make this happen! 

Video coming soon.

Risks & Challenges

A challenge is to spread the word of this campaign far enough, so if you can't contribute, please help get the word out so we can bring this dream to fruition!

story:
Creating a Community Arts Center in Western Maine 

Who we are

I’m Donna D’Aquino, and together with Lauren Head, we are working to realize a dream we have for a community art center and gallery in our town of Bethel, Maine. Lauren and I both have quite a bit of experience in the arts, both in teaching and in making. Combined with a landlord who shares our vision for this project, we believe we have the perfect formula for success. 

Being the eternal optimists that artists often are, we BELIEVE this can, and will work. It WILL enrich our community and environment here in Western Maine.

What we have done

We are off to a great start! We have pooled our resources and rolled up our sleeves to transform our storefront shop (one of the three spaces available to us) into a beautiful gallery, classroom, and workspace. (Check out our before and after photos in the photo gallery!) 

We opened our storefront at 57 MAINe ARTS on December 12, 2015, and have taught several classes and welcomed community members through our doors.

Where we are headed

We have access to additional teaching space in the building (which is still in need of some work) and also are hoping to transform the larger space into a gallery where we will be able to show more work and curate exhibitions. 

What we need

We need your help to keep this moving forward and to purchase the tools and supplies we need to teach and cover basic operational costs in our low season. While $25,000 is not enough to keep us afloat for the next 24 months, it will be a HUGE help. Your donations will help support the vision of 57 MAINe Arts over the next 24 months by which time we believe we will have achieved sustainability. 

Your Support

Here’s the items we need and which your support will help us acquire: 

Donations welcome, email here for a complete list and to learn how you can get involved

Classroom Set Up 

•$975 = Tabletop guillotine shear 

•$800 = Rolling mill 

•$760 = Enameling kiln 

•$575 = Polishing motor 

•$495 = Soldering set up including regulator, hose, hand-piece, tips

•$395 = Jeweler’s workbench

•$154 = Foredom drill press vise 

•$135 = Large bench vise

Tools of the Trade: Become a maker. Hammer it out. Cut, twist and mold.

•$53 = Bracelet mandrel 

•$48 = Ring mandrel 

•$45 = Wire cutters

•$28 =  Bezel mandrel 

•$25 = Riveting hammer 

•$20 = Rawhide hammer

•$16 = Face shield 

•$10 = 12 dozen saw blades

•$ 8  = Copper tongs 

•$  6 = Ring clamp 

•$  5 = Fire brick

•$  3 = Tweezers 

The Big Time

•$3785  = Bonny Doon 20-ton hydraulic press

•$3555  = Casting set up

Keeping the doors open and the lights on

•$1000 = 1 month's operating costs (rent, staff and utilities) 

•$  700 = 1 month's rent

•$  300 = 1 week's staffing (40 hrs x $7.50) 

•$    60 = 1 day’s staffing (8 hrs x $7.50)

Give a gift. Choose a perk.

In return for your generous contribution, we are offering PERKS of Donna and Lauren’s handmade work. There is handmade jewelry, sculpture, blacksmith objects and prints. We are also offering classes, and the opportunity to be recognized as one of our sustaining and/or original contributors.

We know you are being asked by so many people for a contribution. We appreciate your consideration of our project! Please help us spread the word by sharing our project with others you think may be interested. Thank you! Thank you! Thank you! 

More about Bethel, Maine

Bethel is a wonderful town and has a very long history of education, as a place of rest and peace, and as a place for many things outdoors. There are exciting things happening here in Bethel, including: Sunday River, one of the largest ski mountains in the east; The Bethel Inn, a four-season resort with an 18-hole golf course;  Gould Academy, a prestigious private high school; and coming soon a world-class Maine Mineral and Gem Museum, the only one of its kind in the country. We feel that an Art Center is the perfect next step for this community.

More on our vision

We believe, that through art, people of all ages can acquire many skills. It fosters creativity and confidence. It helps people to focus, learn problem solving and perseverance. 

In our beautiful Western Maine town, one of the things that is missing is a community place where people can come together, and be exposed to the arts. We want to share the things we are passionate about. We want to bring our experiences and our love of making to this community. We plan to teach art classes for both adults and children. We are also looking forward to teaching with the many different organizations that have already reached out to us.

We understand this is going to take a great deal of work and time, and there are going to be obstacles along the way. We know by example and perseverance we will be able to transcend any difficulties.

Everyone with whom we have spoken is excited and enthusiastic about this coming to the community and your support will help us lay a solid foundation for our vision and programs. 

Thank you, 

Donna and Lauren

57 MAINe ARTS
